text.p: How many linear transformations [mathjaxinline]T:\mathbb R^4 \rightarrow \mathbb R^2[/mathjaxinline] satisfy the conditions [mathjaxinline]T(e_1) = T(e_3) = \left[\begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 3 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]T(e_4) = \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline]?

choice.text: more than one but finitely many

font.p: This question is equivalent to asking 'how many [mathjaxinline]2\times 4[/mathjaxinline] real matrices [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] satisfy [mathjaxinline]A e_1=A\cdot e_3=\left[\begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 3 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]Ae_4=\mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline]?'. The first equality forces the first and third columns of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] to both be [mathjaxinline]\left[\begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 3 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline], and the second equality forces the fourth column of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] to be [mathjaxinline]\mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline], but the third column of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] is free to have any real entries. Thus there are infinitely many choices.
